content:
Last year, I completed a formal proof of GÃ¶del's first incompleteness theorem, and this time, I have finished formalizing the proof of second incompleteness theorem. I proved that a theory TTT, which is stronger than IÎ£1\mathsf{I}\Sigma_1IÎ£1â€‹â€‹, Î”1\Delta_1Î”1â€‹-definable, and has N\mathbb{N}N as a model, cannot prove or disprove a statement asserting its own consistency:

theorem goedel_second_incompleteness [ğˆğšºâ‚ â‰¼ T] [T.Delta1Definable] [System.Consistent T] :
    T âŠ¬ â†‘ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»

theorem consistent_undecidable [ğˆğšºâ‚ â‰¼ T] [T.Delta1Definable] [â„• âŠ§â‚˜* T] :
    System.Undecidable T â†‘ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»
  • goedel_second_incompleteness
  • consistent_undecidable

The formal proof of G2 has already been done using Isabelle, but my result is stronger. The result in Isabelle is based on the theory of hereditary finite sets (HF\mathsf{HF}HF), which is equivalent to Peano arithmetic, but I proved it for a weaker theory, IÎ£1\mathsf{I}\Sigma_1IÎ£1â€‹. This is likely the first formalization.

I also showed a stronger result on the first incompleteness theorem than before, proving the incompleteness of Cobham's R0\mathsf{R}_0R0â€‹. R0\mathsf{R}_0R0â€‹ is a theory of arithmetic weaker than Robinson's Q\mathsf{Q}Q, known as the weakest theory where essential incompleteness holds. This is also likely the first formalization of this.

theorem goedel_first_incompleteness [ğ‘â‚€ â‰¼ T] [T.Delta1Definable] [Sigma1Sound T] :
    Â¬System.Complete T
  • goedel_first_incompleteness

In addition, there are several important theorems as byproducts, which I hope to include in mathlib in the future.

  • The exponential function's graph can be expressed by a Î£0\Sigma_0Î£0â€‹-formula of arithmetic.
  • RE=Î£1â€‹\mathbf{RE} = \mathbf{\Sigma_1}â€‹RE=Î£1â€‹â€‹.

There are a few things to note. First, the definition of the arithmetical hierarchy differs slightly from the standard one. Typically, Î£n\Sigma_nÎ£nâ€‹/Î n\Pi_nÎ nâ€‹-formula is defined as a formula with quantifiers alternating nnn times starting with âˆƒ\existsâˆƒ/âˆ€\forallâˆ€, but in my formalization, Î£n\Sigma_nÎ£nâ€‹/Î n\Pi_nÎ nâ€‹â€‹ is defined as those closed by âˆ§\landâˆ§/âˆ¨\lorâˆ¨/bounded quantifiers. However, since it is known that IÎ£nâŠ¢IÎ£0(Î£n)\mathsf{I}\Sigma_n \vdash \mathsf{I}\Sigma_0(\Sigma_n)IÎ£nâ€‹âŠ¢IÎ£0â€‹(Î£nâ€‹), there is no issue in terms of the provability strength of IÎ£n\mathsf{I}\Sigma_nIÎ£nâ€‹.

Also, I adopted Tait-calculus as a proof system. Tait-calculus has fewer inference rules, making the formalization easier to handle, but the formulas themselves must satisfy the De Morgan rules. Because of this, it is not directly compatible with ModelTheory in mathlib.
Just checking what you mean by saying "the formulas themselves must satisfy the De Morgan rules" - do you mean that you're requiring that not/neg isn't part of the inductive definition?

That's right. Formulas are defined as

Aâˆ£Bâˆ£R(vâƒ—)âˆ£Râ€¾(vâƒ—)âˆ£âŠ¤âˆ£âŠ¥âˆ£Aâˆ§Bâˆ£Aâˆ¨Bâˆ£âˆ€Aâˆ£âˆƒAA | B | R(\vec{v}) | \overline{R}(\vec{v}) | \top | \bot | A \land B | A \lor B | \forall A | \exists AAâˆ£Bâˆ£R(v)âˆ£R(v)âˆ£âŠ¤âˆ£âŠ¥âˆ£Aâˆ§Bâˆ£Aâˆ¨Bâˆ£âˆ€Aâˆ£âˆƒA

and negation is defined inductively.

Â¬R(vâƒ—)â‰”Râ€¾(vâƒ—)\lnot R(\vec{v}) \coloneqq \overline{R}(\vec{v})Â¬R(v):=R(v)
Â¬Râ€¾(vâƒ—)â‰”R(vâƒ—)\lnot\overline{R}(\vec{v}) \coloneqq R(\vec{v})Â¬R(v):=R(v)
Â¬âŠ¤â‰”âŠ¥\lnot\top \coloneqq \botÂ¬âŠ¤:=âŠ¥
Â¬âŠ¥â‰”âŠ¤\lnot\bot \coloneqq \topÂ¬âŠ¥:=âŠ¤
Â¬(Aâˆ§B)â‰”Â¬Aâˆ¨Â¬B\lnot(A \land B) \coloneqq \lnot A \lor \lnot BÂ¬(Aâˆ§B):=Â¬Aâˆ¨Â¬B
Â¬(Aâˆ¨B)â‰”Â¬Aâˆ§Â¬B\lnot(A \lor B) \coloneqq \lnot A \land \lnot BÂ¬(Aâˆ¨B):=Â¬Aâˆ§Â¬B
Â¬âˆ€Aâ‰”âˆƒÂ¬A\lnot\forall A \coloneqq \exists \lnot AÂ¬âˆ€A:=âˆƒÂ¬A
Â¬âˆƒAâ‰”âˆ€Â¬A\lnot\exists A \coloneqq \forall \lnot AÂ¬âˆƒA:=âˆ€Â¬A

Also in ModelTheory the equality symbol is always included in the atomic formula, but not in my formalization. However, it would be possible to define appropriate translations between each other.

Cool! Could you say what the language and axioms for R_0 are in the usual mathematical vernacular? I guess this is the formal definition: https://github.com/FormalizedFormalLogic/Foundation/blob/41ecee31d573798ea47f005189841c76041090b5/Logic/FirstOrder/Arith/Theory.lean#L21-L26

I think I'm most mystified by leastNumber...

In my formalization, Language of R0\mathsf{R}_0R0â€‹ is LORâ‰”{0,1,+,â‹…,=,<}\mathcal{L}_\mathrm{OR} \coloneqq \{0, 1, +, \cdot, =, <\}LORâ€‹:={0,1,+,â‹…,=,<}, and R0\mathsf{R}_0R0â€‹ consists of axioms of equality and following infinite axioms.
Î©1:nâ€¾+mâ€¾=n+mâ€¾\Omega_1: \overline{n} + \overline{m} = \overline{n + m}Î©1â€‹:n+m=n+mâ€‹ for all n,mâˆˆNn, m \in \mathbb{N}n,mâˆˆN
Î©2:nâ€¾â‹…mâ€¾=nmâ€¾\Omega_2: \overline{n} \cdot \overline{m} = \overline{n m}Î©2â€‹:nâ‹…m=nm for all n,mâˆˆNn, m \in \mathbb{N}n,mâˆˆN
Î©3:nâ€¾â‰ mâ€¾\Omega_3: \overline{n} \neq \overline{m}Î©3â€‹:nî€ =m for all n,mâˆˆNn, m \in \mathbb{N}n,mâˆˆN, such that nâ‰ mn \ne mnî€ =m
Î©4:(âˆ€x)[x<nâ€¾â†”x=0â€¾âˆ¨x=1â€¾âˆ¨â‹¯âˆ¨x=nâˆ’1â€¾]\Omega_4: (\forall x)[x < \overline{n} \leftrightarrow x = \overline{0} \lor x = \overline{1} \lor \cdots \lor x = \overline{n - 1}]Î©4â€‹:(âˆ€x)[x<nâ†”x=0âˆ¨x=1âˆ¨â‹¯âˆ¨x=nâˆ’1â€‹] for all nâˆˆNn \in \mathbb{N}nâˆˆN
nâ€¾\overline{n}n is a numeral of nnn, defined as
nâ€¾â‰”{1+â‹¯+1âŸnifÂ nâ‰ 00ifÂ n=0 \overline{n} \coloneqq \begin{cases} \underbrace{1 + \cdots + 1}_{n} & \text{if } n \ne 0 \\ 0 & \text{if } n = 0\end{cases}n:=â©â¨â§â€‹n1+â‹¯+1â€‹â€‹0â€‹ifÂ nî€ =0ifÂ n=0â€‹

leastNumber is the least number principle LÏ†\mathsf{L}\varphiLÏ†, but it is just defined and not used.

This is really cool!
Could you explain why the exponential function's graph is sigma 0? I can't figure it out

Technically, the proof is quite complex. The core of the proof is to use the definition of exponential (2x2^x2x) by prefix induction used by Buss.

20:=122n:=2nâ‹…2n22n+1:=2â‹…2nâ‹…2n2^0 := 1 \\ 2^{2n} := 2^n \cdot 2^n \\ 2^{2n + 1} := 2 \cdot 2^n \cdot 2^n20:=122n:=2nâ‹…2n22n+1:=2â‹…2nâ‹…2n

The proof can be found in Logical Foundations of Proof Complexity by Cook & Nguyen or Metamathematics of First-Order Arithmetic by Hajek & Pudlak.
I opened a PR to update the Freek's list. #16968
